title: Count Users by City
markdown:
# **Count Users by City**

**Difficulty:** Medium  •  **Tags:** `COUNT` • `GROUP BY`



## **Problem Description**

Write a SQL query to count the number of users in each city.



## **Table Schema**

**users**
```
+--------+------+
| Column | Type |
+--------+------+
| id     | INT  |
| name   | TEXT |
| city   | TEXT |
+--------+------+
```



## **Example**

### **Input**

**users**
```
+----+---------+------+
| id | name    | city |
+----+---------+------+
| 1  | Alice   | NYC  |
| 2  | Bob     | LA   |
| 3  | Charlie | NYC  |
| 4  | David   | LA   |
| 5  | Eve     | NYC  |
+----+---------+------+
```

### **Expected Output**

```
+------+------------+
| city | user_count |
+------+------------+
| LA   | 2          |
| NYC  | 3          |
+------+------------+
```

testCases.setupSql: CREATE TABLE users(id INT, name TEXT, city TEXT); INSERT INTO users VALUES (1,'Alice','NYC'),(2,'Bob','LA'),(3,'Charlie','NYC'),(4,'David','LA'),(5,'Eve','NYC');
testCases.solutionSql: SELECT city, COUNT(*) as user_count FROM users GROUP BY city;

testCases.setupSql: CREATE TABLE users(id INT, name TEXT, city TEXT);
testCases.solutionSql: SELECT city, COUNT(*) as user_count FROM users GROUP BY city;

testCases.setupSql: CREATE TABLE users(id INT, name TEXT, city TEXT); INSERT INTO users VALUES (1,'Alice','NYC'),(2,'Bob','LA'),(3,'Charlie','NYC'),(4,'David','LA'),(5,'Eve','NYC');
testCases.solutionSql: SELECT city, COUNT(*) as user_count FROM users GROUP BY city;
